text.text_translated:
Dogs live in groups. They learn that people give food to small, cute dogs more. So, the group sends these dogs to beg for food for everyone.
Some dogs learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know how dogs get off the train at the right time.
One idea is this: Dogs have a very, very good sense of smell. They learn to recognise the special smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn to recognise station names. They hear these names in train announcements.
People on the metro see dogs often now. They are very used to seeing them. So, locals do not notice the dogs much.

feedback.feedback: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6836 is below the required 0.75. The core message and nuances of the original text were not sufficiently preserved. Specific issues include: 1. The phrase 'more likely to give food' in the original implies a probability, which was simplified to 'give food... more', suggesting frequency instead. This alters the original meaning. 2. The original's 'even learnt' conveys a sense of surprise or advanced skill, which is lost in the simpler 'learn'. 3. The strong causal link in the original's final sentence, 'so used to... that they travel largely unnoticed', is weakened in the rewrite. The original emphasizes the direct consequence of familiarity leading to being unnoticed, while the rewrite separates these ideas, reducing the impact of the dogs being 'largely unnoticed' as a direct result. Suggestion: Rephrase sentences to more accurately reflect the original's nuances of probability, surprising skill, and direct cause-and-effect relationships, ensuring the MeaningBERT score improves.

best_attempt.text_translated:
Dogs live in groups. They learn that people give food to small, cute dogs more. So, the group sends these dogs to beg for food for everyone.
It is surprising. Some dogs learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know how dogs get off the train at the right time.
One idea is this: Dogs have a very, very good sense of smell. They learn to recognise the special smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: Maybe they learn to recognise station names. They hear these names in train announcements.
People on the metro see dogs often now. They are very used to seeing them. So, locals do not notice the dogs.
